data.title: Paessler
data.meta_description: Helping customers monitor their entire IT infrastructure 24/7, Paessler AG keeps up
data.text:
Greg noticed the functionality and potential of GitLab pipelines, and adopted them for the cloud team he works on, and itâs since caught on all over the organization.

âBefore we had our build pipeline running with Jenkins,â explained Konstantin. âSo, we have a develop, release, and master branch, which is finally released to the public. Every time you build a branch of those three, the outcome would have been installs on several VMs and then our test automation started in a separate process. At the end of the process you got an email that it worked, it didnât work, where it failed, and stuff like that.â

This sequential process, with feedback only available at the end, was only triggered automatically on the dev, release and master branches. A QA engineer had to perform some tasks to make this happen, around 10 minutes, 6-7 times a day. If other branches needed testing theyâd have to build them locally and run a test locally.

The situation now could not be more different with the use of GitLab: âEvery branch gets tested,â said Greg. âItâs built into the pipeline. As soon as you commit your code, the whole process kicks off to get it tested. Then you can go to the branchâs review app and have a running version of PRTG that youâve just checked in code for, thatâs already also been tested.â What this means in practice is higher quality control for their product and a significantly tighter feedback loop between developers and QA.

âThe amount of effort involved in actually getting to the newest version that youâre supposed to be testing, whether youâre a developer or a QA engineer, is minimized immensely.â The QA engineerâs tasks â about an hour a day in total â have been slashed to 30 seconds, a 120x speed increase.

This automation really pays dividends when something is wrong: if the tests fail, the pipeline fails, so the developer already knows something has gone awry, instead of waiting to hear that from QA. This immediate feedback now has developers at Paessler self-serving 90 percent of their QA.

While itâs sometimes a challenge to drive widespread adoption of a new tool within an organization, the uptake of GitLab CI/CD at Paessler has been remarkable. âIt really started catching on when people just saw our pipelines,â Greg said. âWe actually had an internal learning session that was basically, âYou show us yours, and weâll show you ours.â Everybody showed off their pipelines just to see what theyâre capable of, what people are doing with them, to get new ideas and stuff like that. It was actually a pretty successful, interesting session.â

âGitLab is being used like crazy. And now that thereâs a bunch of cool stuff going on in it, everybody wants to jump on the bandwagon.â
